section.heading: Reapplication, Changes, Timely and Adequate Notice.

para.text: Reapplication.
The local department shall:
Assign a period of eligibility as described in Regulation .05D of this chapter, after which a new application is required;
Notify a recipient when a reapplication is required; and
Schedule an interview for a reapplication in time to provide uninterrupted benefits.
A reapplication is treated the same as an application.
Interim Change.
The local department shall advise applicants and recipients of the change reporting requirements.

An applicant or recipient who fails to report receipt of or a change in countable income, as required by this section, loses the earnings disregards as described in Regulation .13E(3)(b) of this chapter for the period of time the change was unreported.
A recipient shall report:
Any change in circumstance that may affect the amount of payment to the local department within 10 days of the change; and
New employment within 10 days of receipt of the first pay.
The effective date of a grant change shall be made as follows:
Except as provided in paragraph (b) of this section, unless TCA is continued pending disposition of an appeal, the effective date of the grant change is:
The first day of the month immediately following the month in which the change occurred; or
Not later than the first day of the second subsequent month following the month in which the change occurred.

Unless TCA is continued pending disposition of an appeal, if the change in circumstance involves new employment, the effective date of the grant change shall be no later than 10 days following the receipt of the first pay upon the participant obtaining employment.
When TCA is terminated for any reason, continued eligibility for Medical Assistance shall be reevaluated for the assistance unit.

If the assistance unit becomes ineligible because of a parent's earnings and the assistance unit has received TCA in 3 of the last 6 months, the assistance unit is eligible to receive child care for an additional 12 months, based on the caretaker relative's income.
After the termination of TCA the local department shall provide transitional food supplement benefits as described in COMAR 07.03.17.49H.
An assistance unit that becomes ineligible for TCA solely because of increased collection of child support is eligible for 4 additional months of Medical Assistance.
Recipients may request that their case be closed at any time.
Adequate Notice.
The local department shall provide a FIP recipient with written notice of any change.
Except as provided in §C(3) of this regulation, the written notice shall include:
A statement of what action the local department intends to take;
The reasons for the intended action;
The specific regulations supporting the action;
An explanation of the individual's right to request an administrative hearing;
The circumstances under which assistance is continued if an administrative hearing is requested; and

The appellant's obligation to repay any benefits issued during the appeal period if the administrative hearing results in a determination that the appellant was ineligible for benefits that were issued pending appeal.
When changes in either State or federal law require automatic benefit adjustments for categories of recipients, timely notice of a grant adjustment shall be given, which is adequate if it includes:
A statement of what action the local department intends to take;
The reasons for the intended action;
A statement of a specific change in law requiring the action;
An explanation of the individual's right to request an administrative hearing;
The circumstances under which assistance is continued if an administrative hearing is requested; and

The appellant's obligation to repay any benefits issued during the appeal period if the administrative hearing results in a determination that the appellant was ineligible for benefits that were issued pending appeal.
Timely Notice of Termination or Reduction.

The local department shall mail or hand deliver written advance notice at least 10 calendar days before the date of a reduction, termination, or suspension action except as described in §D(2) of this regulation.
Exceptions to timely notice are:
Death of the recipient;
The recipient's whereabouts are unknown, after exploring all available information;
The recipient has been accepted for assistance in a new jurisdiction;
The TCA child is removed from the home by a court or is placed in foster care; or
The recipient requests, in writing, that the case be closed.
Conciliation Process.
Conciliation and sanction are applied to recipient assistance units only.
The local department shall allow one 30-day conciliation period for each recipient’s failure to comply with requirements for each of the following:
Work as specified in Regulation .07-1 of this chapter;
Child support as specified in Regulation .10A of this chapter;
Substance abuse treatment and testing as specified in Regulation .09 of this chapter;
Long term disability requirements as specified in Regulation .08A and B of this chapter; and
Minor parent school enrollment and attendance as specified in Regulation s.07H and .07-1 of this chapter.
During the 30-day period, the case manager shall advise the individual of the noncompliance and help the individual to comply by:
Sending the individual a letter to schedule a conciliation conference;
Following up on the letter through telephone contact or personal contact as appropriate and feasible;
Investigating with the individual any barriers or good cause reasons for the noncompliance; and
Assisting the individual in resolving the barriers to compliance.
After the 30-day period, a later instance of noncompliance with the same program requirement does not entitle the individual to another 30-day conciliation period.
Sanctions for Noncompliance.
Except as provided in Regulation .09D and E of this chapter for substance abuse, when an adult recipient is found to be in noncompliance with program requirements, the:
Entire assistance unit is ineligible; and
Case manager shall:
Investigate the reasons for noncompliance; and
Make personal contact with the assistance unit to the extent it is appropriate and feasible.
When a child is found to be in noncompliance with program requirements, the:
Child remains a member of the assistance unit;
Child’s incremental portion of the grant is deducted from the family’s TCA grant; and
Case manager shall:
Investigate the reasons for noncompliance; and
Make personal contact with the assistance unit to the extent it is appropriate and feasible.
When implementing a sanction:
For a first instance of noncompliance, a sanction may not be imposed less than 30 days from the first written notice of noncompliance with a program requirement, and:
TCA shall be resumed immediately upon compliance with the work activity; or
If the noncompliance continues into a new month, TCA shall be prorated from the day after the day of compliance;
For a second or subsequent instance of noncompliance, a sanction may be imposed:
After the case manager investigates the reasons for the noncompliance;
Following adequate and timely adverse action; or
TCA shall be resumed and prorated from the day after the 10 calendar day period during which the sanctioned individual complied with the work activity for all available activity days; or

For a third and any subsequent instance of noncompliance, TCA shall be resumed and prorated from the day after the 30 calendar day period during which the sanctioned individual complied with the work activity for all available activity days.
If an individual fails to comply during a sanction period without good cause:
The sanction period shall start over;
No additional instance of noncompliance is counted against the noncomplying individual; and
The TCA benefit may not be resumed until compliance is met.
All individuals in the assistance unit are sanctioned except a child who is:
Placed with another caretaker relative by the Social Services Administration;
In the legal custody of another caretaker relative; or
Living with another caretaker relative when the sanctioned caretaker relative is institutionalized.
Transitional Assistance.

After termination of TCA, transitional assistance may be available to assistance units in which an adult is not in compliance with a work requirement to the extent that a third-party payee is available to administer funds.

Upon a determination that transitional assistance shall be provided, the TCA that would have been paid to the assistance unit shall be paid instead to a third-party payee on behalf of the recipient for a period not to exceed 3 months.
Priority for transitional assistance shall be given to an assistance unit with:
An active child protective service case;
An active intensive family service case;
An adult member who is disabled;
An adult member who is illiterate; or
An adult member who is not fluent in English if notices are not translated in the individual's language.

Sanctions for Fraud and IPV. An assistance unit is ineligible for TCA benefits upon a finding of fraud or an IPV by a court of law, through an administrative disqualification hearing, or through the waiver of an administrative disqualification hearing in accordance with the requirements in COMAR 07.03.10.
Fraudulent Misrepresentation of Residence.
An individual is ineligible for TCA for a period of 10 years when the individual fraudulently misrepresents residence to obtain benefits from two or more states.

The 10 years begins with the date the individual is convicted in federal or state court of having made a fraudulent statement or representation in order to receive assistance simultaneously from two or more states.
All of the income of the convicted individual is counted as available to the remaining assistance unit members.

A parent or caretaker who fails to report the absence of a dependent child, when the absence is expected to be more than 180 days, is not eligible for assistance for 3 consecutive months, according to the following:
The absence shall be reported by the end of a 5 calendar day period that begins with the date it becomes clear that the child is absent;
The income and assets of the parent are counted as being available to the remaining assistance unit members; and
The 3 months shall begin the first day of the month following the adverse action period.
24-Month Time Limit.
An adult parent receiving assistance shall engage in work, when appropriate child care is available, as defined by the local department of social services, at the earlier of when the:
Local department determines that the parent is ready to engage in work in accordance with UE requirements in Regulation .07-1 of this chapter; or
Parent has received assistance for 24 cumulative months under TCA funded wholly or in part by federal funds.
The only exception to the 24-month work requirement is a single parent caring for a child younger than 6 years old who is unable to obtain child care for one or more of the following reasons:
Unavailability of appropriate child care within a reasonable distance from the parent's home or work site;
Unavailability or unsuitability of informal child care by a relative or others; or
Unavailability or unsuitability of appropriate and affordable formal child care arrangements.
60-Month Time Limit.

Unless exempt because of hardship, TCA may not be paid for an adult parent who has received a total of 60 cumulative months of TCA funded wholly or in part by federal funds in Maryland and all other states.
In determining the number of months for which assistance has been paid to an adult parent, those months do not count in which the individual was:
A minor child and not the head of household or married to the head of household;
Determined to be a victim of domestic or family violence and receiving counseling;
Disabled for 12 or more months, applied for Supplemental Security Income, and repaid the State when SSI benefits were paid;
A needy TCA recipient who was not a parent but was included in the TCA grant; or
Working and eligible because of the TCA earned income disregard as provided in Regulation .13E(3)(b) of this chapter.
The local department shall determine an adult parent exempt because of hardship if:
There is a current signed family independence plan that states the:
Requirements and other actions the parent shall meet; and
Support services the local department shall provide;
There is an initial and updated assessment; and
There is documentation to support the local department's determination that the adult parent has:
Been offered or provided the support services in accordance with a family independence plan;
Demonstrated a good faith effort to satisfy work activities specified in the family independence plan; and
Encountered significant barriers beyond the parent's control that prevented finding and keeping a job.

The local department shall determine an adult parent exempt because of hardship if there is documentation that the local department did not offer or provide the support services to the family as specified in the family independence plan.
The local department shall use the following procedures to determine if an adult parent is exempt because of hardship:
The case manager shall document in the case record the:
Initial and updated assessments;
Local department's maintenance of a family independence plan that is currently in effect;
Family's good-faith efforts to meet the terms and conditions of the family independence plan; and
Local department's efforts to ensure that the terms and conditions of the family independence plan have been fulfilled.
The case manager shall make a recommendation based on the family's record as to:
Whether a hardship exemption should be granted to the family; and
The reasons why the exemption should or should not be granted;
The recommendation shall include a determination as to whether the local department was able to make the support services available to the family as specified in the plan;
If the local department determines that an adult parent is exempt because of hardship:
The family shall be granted a hardship exemption;
A new assessment shall be completed within 45 days after the hardship exemption is granted; and
A new family independence plan shall be established between the local department and the family within 60 days after the hardship exemption is granted to ensure independence as quickly as possible.

If required by the provision of §B(5)(d) of this regulation, the case manager and the adult parent shall develop, sign, and date a new mutually agreed-upon family independence plan that states what must be done, when, and by whom to:
Overcome the family's barriers to employment;
Assist the family in preparing for the transition to work; and
Ensure that the family becomes independent.
If required by the provision of §B(5)(d) of this regulation, the new family independence plan shall include, but is not limited to, the following:
A statement of the goals and intent of the plan;
A statement or list of the problems or barriers that shall be overcome to achieve the goals of the plan;

A list of the services and supports that the case manager and the local department shall provide to assist the family, as appropriate to the plan, as well as the time frames in which these services will be provided; and
A list of the responsibilities and activities that the family shall undertake and accomplish, as appropriate to the plan, and the time frames in which each task shall be completed.
The case manager's recommendation and any new plan, if required, shall be reviewed and approved by the following:
A FIP supervisor; and
The director of the local department or designee.
In accordance with Regulation .22A of this chapter, the Department shall review a sample of TCA cases closed pursuant to this section.

Adult parents exempt because of hardship, who exceed the numerical limits of federal law, shall be paid TCA entirely from State general funds that may be counted toward any federal maintenance of effort requirement.
Adult parents paid under §B(10) of this regulation are subject to all FIP requirements in this chapter.

section.heading: Payment Irregularities.
section.text: Payment irregularities, which include overpayments, underpayments, fraud, and recoupment of funds, are handled according to COMAR 07.03.14.

para.text: The Family Investment Administration shall review TCA cases.
An individual who refuses to cooperate in the quality control review is subject to termination of cash assistance or service as provided in §D of this regulation.
An individual whose case is terminated for refusal to cooperate in a quality control review may apply for and receive assistance if otherwise eligible in the future, if the individual:
Participates in the review that resulted in the case closure;
Cooperates completely in supplying all information as required concerning current eligibility; and
Is otherwise eligible.

An individual whose case is terminated for refusal to cooperate in a quality control review shall have benefits restored in the following manner when the individual cooperates with the quality control review:
During the first no-pay month, the full monthly benefit is paid; or
After the first no-pay month, the individual is treated as an applicant and the benefit is prorated.
Agency Conference. A FIP recipient may request an agency conference to:
Obtain an explanation of the reasons for proposed actions; and
Present information to show that the proposed action is incorrect.

Appeal of Local Department Decision. The local department shall give to each applicant or recipient of FIP written notification of the right to and procedures for requesting and obtaining an administrative hearing as set forth in COMAR 07.01.04.
Discrimination.

The local department may not discriminate against any FIP applicant or recipient on the grounds of race, color, national origin, gender, age, marital status, mental or physical disability, or religious or political affiliation.
A FIP applicant or recipient may file a written complaint which sets forth the events and circumstances of alleged discrimination with the:
Secretary;
Local department;
Department's Constituent Services Office;
Departmental Equal Opportunity Officer; or
Office of Civil Rights, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Region III, Philadelphia, PA.
The Department shall investigate promptly and notify the complainant of its findings within 60 days of the filing of a written complaint.
In this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated:
"Displacement" means employing or assigning a subsidized participant when:

The employer has terminated the employment of an employee, or the employee's current position, or otherwise caused an involuntary reduction in its work force in order to fill the vacancy with a subsidized participant;
An individual is hired while another person is on layoff, including seasonal layoff, from the same or substantially equivalent position;
The employer has reduced the hours of an employee in the same or substantially equivalent position to less than full time in order to employ or assign a subsidized participant; or
The employment or assignment results in the impairment of an existing contract for services.
"Employer" means a person or government entity which employs at least one individual within the State.
Subsidized Employment.
"Subsidized employment" means employment in the public or private sector which is supported in part by federal or State funds for a limited time.
"Subsidized employment" does not include employment for which an employer receives a tax credit.
"Subsidized employment" includes benefit diversion in which the participant's cash assistance and food stamp benefits are diverted to an employer to subsidize compensation paid to the participant.
"Subsidized participant" means an adult in a family receiving TCA under FIP who is engaged in subsidized employment or work experience.
"Unsubsidized employment" means employment in the public or private sector which is:
Not supported by federal or State FIP funds; and
Employment which is an arrangement solely between the employer and the employee.
"Work experience" means time-limited preparation for employment in a public or private work setting.
Work experience participants:
Are not employees and remain recipients of TCA, Medical Assistance, and, in many cases, food stamps; and
May receive an expense allowance but not wages.
A TCA recipient may fill a vacant employment position to engage in a work activity.
A TCA recipient may not be employed or assigned in a work activity funded in whole or in part with federal funds or with State funds which results in the displacement of an employee.
Work activities subject to this regulation include:
Unsubsidized employment;
Subsidized employment;
Subsidized public sector employment;
Work experience;
On-the-job training; and
Community service.
An employee who feels employment was lost due to displacement may initiate a grievance by presenting:
The complaint to the local department in writing not later than 30 calendar days after the:
Alleged cause of the complaint; or
Employee knew or should have known of the alleged cause of complaint; and
Information to the local department to support the allegation that the employee was displaced.
The local department shall:
Schedule a conference with the employee, or with the employer and the employee, within 10 calendar days after receipt of the complaint;
Within 15 calendar days from the date of the conference with the employee:
Determine whether displacement occurred and send written notice to the employee and employer of the local department decision; and

Notify the employee and employer in writing that, if either disagrees with the decision, either has a right to request a conference before the Welfare Displacement Review Panel which shall be comprised of:
Two representatives from the Department;
One representative from the Maryland Department of Labor; and
Two public representatives appointed by the Secretary.
A written request under §G(2)(b) of this regulation shall be filed with the Family Investment Administration not later than 15 days from the date of the local department decision.
The Welfare Displacement Review Panel shall:
Hold a conference with the employer and employee within 30 days of receipt of the request; and
Within 30 days from the date of the conference:
Render a decision upholding, reversing, or modifying the local department decision;
Notify the employee, the employer, and the local department, in writing, of the panel's decision; and

Give each employee and employer written notification that, if either disagrees with the Welfare Displacement Review Panel's decision, each has a right to request an administrative hearing in the same manner that a recipient would request an administrative hearing under COMAR 07.01.04.
Office of Administrative Hearings (OAH).
The OAH shall conduct the hearing in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, COMAR 28.02.01 and 07.01.04, and this regulation.
Notice of the hearing shall be sent to the parties at least 15 days before the hearing and shall advise the parties of the right to be represented by a lawyer or other individual at the hearing.
A party may examine the Department's record for the purpose of discovering information pertinent to the appeal, if information the Department is required to keep confidential is protected.
A hearing is open to the public.
The employee bears the burden of proof.
The administrative law judge shall:
Determine whether displacement occurred;
Issue the final administrative decision not later than 90 days after the date of the request for the hearing; and
Send a copy of the decision to the parties and to the local department.
The decision of the administrative law judge is:
Binding on the local department; and
Subject to review by the circuit court.
Upon a final finding of displacement in the grievance process, the local department may:
End the subsidy in the case of subsidized employment; and
Remove the participant from work experience, on-the-job training, or community service.

The Secretary of the Department and the Executive Director of the Family Investment Administration, or their designees, shall develop partnership agreements for the exchange of information with any entities necessary to assist in the verification of cash assistance eligibility.
The agreements shall be in writing and shall:
Include procedures for requesting, obtaining, and examining the information;
Specify the Secretary's designee for requesting and receiving information by title or position; and
Include reimbursement rates.
Reimbursement rates are based on reasonable and necessary costs of providing the information.
Grants.
Demonstration projects shall be developed in partnership with the local department through grants approved by the Department to:
Nonprofit organizations;
Local education agencies;
Local management boards;
Local health departments;
Religious organizations; and
Institutions of higher education.

A religious organization may participate in FIP on the same basis as any other nongovernment entity. The funds allocated to demonstration projects may not be used to further sectarian religious instruction or worship.
An individual is not required to accept assistance from a religious organization if acceptance would violate the individual's bona fide religious beliefs and practices.
All individuals receiving benefits under FIP shall be provided with clear and timely notice of their rights in accordance with the requirements of Article 88A, §47, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Request for Proposal.
The Secretary shall award grants for demonstration projects through a competitive bid process which includes the:
Issuance of a request for proposal in accordance with the requirements of Article 88A, §53, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Establishment of an evaluation panel to review competing proposals and to recommend to the Secretary those proposals which have the greatest programmatic and financial merit.
The request for proposal for demonstration projects shall include requirements that:
Applicants specify what goods or services they will provide to participants; and
Each demonstration project shall:
Complement the local department FIP plan; and
Address specific unmet local needs and barriers that prevent families from meeting the requirements of FIP.
